transportation.taxi: Yellow taxi's are common but don't use meters. App rides are generally safer and prices are clearer.
transportation.buses: Cheap but oftern crowded, unpredictable, and not recommended for foreigners unfamilier with the area.
transportation.walking: Kabul is not a very pedestrian-friendly city. Sidewalks are uneven or missing and traffic can be chaotic. Avoid walking at night.
transportation.airport: Use official airport taxis or arrange a hotel pickup in advance. Avoid accepting rides from individuals inside or outside the terminals.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are the most common way for visitors to get around. The fares are cash and negotiated in advance similarily to Kabul.
transportation.buses: Local buses and operate without a route map.
transportation.walking: The center around the Blue Mosque and bazaar's is walkable but similar to Kabul the sidewalks and traffic is unpredictable.
transportation.airport: Taxis are the primary way to go between the airport and the city and many hotels offer aiport pickup.

popular attractions: Khwaja Abd Allah Ansari Shrine (Gazar Gah)

transportation.taxi: Taxis are widely available but make sure to agree on the fare before starting the trip.
transportation.buses: Does not have a city bus network but has intercity buses that are limited. When inside the city, minibuses are cheap but often crowded.
transportation.walking: Historical area around Herat are walkable by day and be mindful of surroundings at night.
transportation.airport: Taxis are the most reliable airport connection to and from airport. A formal public airport shuttle bus does not exist but many hotels are able to organize airport pickup and dropoff.

popular attractions: Miradouro da Lua (Viewpoint of the Moon)

transportation.taxi: Most taxis are yellow and blue and they do not always use meters so agree on a fare before starting the trip. Ride-hailing apps like Yango and Heetch are also available in Luanda.
transportation.buses: Shared minibuses are available but are often crowded and route information is confusing for foreigners. Not recommended for first-time visitors. Government buses cover different routes but are unpredictable and can be crowded.
transportation.walking: Certain areas of Luanda are walkable during the day such as the Marginal area along the coast and the city center. Avoid walking at night due to safety concerns.
transportation.airport: Services such as Yango, Heetch, an Allo are available in Luanda for transportation. Many hotels provide airport pickup and droppoff.

transportation.taxi: Agree on fare before starting the trip and they are easly found near hotels or central areas. Local ride-hailing apps may be available but are inconsistent.
transportation.buses: Shared minibuses are available but are often crowded and route information is confusing for foreigners. Not recommended for first-time visitors.
transportation.walking: The city center and markets are walkable but be cautious when walking at night.
transportation.airport: Ride to center of city is about 10-15 minutes and the most reliable transportation options would be taxis or prearranged hotel shuttles.

popular attractions: Cathedral of Our Lady of Pópulo
Art Deco Architecture in City Center

transportation.taxi: Blue and white shared taxis (Candongueiros) are the norm, but private taxis are safer for tourists. Always negotiate the fare beforehand.
transportation.buses: Intercity buses (Macon) are reliable for getting there, but within the city, minibuses are chaotic and routes are not clearly marked.
transportation.walking: The colonial center and beachfront promenade are pleasant and walkable during the day. Exercise caution after dark.
transportation.airport: Catumbela Airport serves the city. Taxis are the main way to reach the center, and arranging a transfer through your hotel is recommended.

transportation.taxi: Official yellow taxis are metered and generally reliable. Ride-hailing via WhatsApp (Speed Taxi, Merr Taxi) is common; Uber is not available. Airport trips have fixed rates (approx. 20-25 EUR).
transportation.buses: City 'Urban' buses are cheap (40 Lek) but often crowded during rush hours. The Rinas Express shuttle runs hourly between the city center and the airport (400 Lek).
transportation.walking: The city center is compact and very walkable, especially around Skanderbeg Square and the trendy Blloku district. Sidewalks in the center are wide and well-maintained.
transportation.airport: Tirana International Airport (TIA) is about 20-30 minutes by car. Hourly shuttle buses and 24/7 taxis are the primary connection methods.

transportation.taxi: Taxis gather near the Port and Friendship Park. They rarely use meters, so it is essential to negotiate and agree on the fare before entering.
transportation.buses: Public buses run frequently to Ksamil and Butrint (100-200 Lek). They are the most affordable option but get extremely crowded in summer. The main bus station is near the Synagogue ruins.
transportation.walking: The 'Xhiro' (evening walk) along the seaside promenade is a cultural staple. The city itself is built on a steep hill, making walking inland physically demanding.
transportation.airport: Sarande has no airport. Most visitors arrive via ferry from Corfu, Greece (30-70 mins) or by a 4-5 hour bus/car ride from Tirana.

popular attractions: Royal Villa of Durrës (King Zog's Villa)

transportation.taxi: Taxis are widely available at the port and along the beach. Always agree on a price beforehand or insist on the meter. Apps are less common than in Tirana.
transportation.buses: Durres is a major transport hub with connections to most Albanian cities. Local buses run along the coast to the southern beach areas (Golem/Plepa).
transportation.walking: The 'Volga' promenade and the historic town center are pedestrian-friendly. The main beach area stretches for kilometers and is best explored on foot.
transportation.airport: Located just 30-40 minutes from Tirana International Airport. A direct shuttle bus (Adis Travel) costs around 600 Lek, or taxis can be hired for ~25-30 EUR.

transportation.taxi: Ubiquitous and relatively affordable. Use the Hala app (via Careem) for easier booking. Taxis use meters and accept cards or cash.
transportation.buses: Extensive network connecting most parts of the city. Requires a Nol card for payment as cash is not accepted on board.
transportation.walking: Walkable in specific areas like Dubai Marina, Downtown, and Al Fahidi during cooler months (November to March). Not recommended during summer heat.
transportation.airport: Dubai International (DXB) is connected via the Metro Red Line. Taxis and ride-sharing (Uber/Careem) are available 24/7.

transportation.taxi: Silver taxis are plentiful and metered. Most drivers speak English. Use the 'Abu Dhabi Taxi' app or Careem.
transportation.buses: Modern air-conditioned buses cover the city and suburbs. Payment is made via the Hafilat smart card.
transportation.walking: The Corniche is a beautiful 8km stretch perfect for walking or cycling. Most other areas require vehicle transport.
transportation.airport: Zayed International Airport (AUH) is about 30 minutes from the city center. Airport buses (A1, A2) run 24/7.

popular attractions: Eye of the Emirates Ferris Wheel

transportation.taxi: Taxis are easily available and essential for getting around. They are metered and have a higher starting rate for trips into Dubai.
transportation.buses: The Mowasalat bus service covers the city well and also provides frequent intercity links to Dubai and Ajman.
transportation.walking: The Al Majaz and Al Qasba areas are very pedestrian-friendly and popular for evening strolls.
transportation.airport: Sharjah International Airport (SHJ) is the hub for Air Arabia. Taxis and public Mowasalat buses connect the airport to the city.

transportation.taxi: Radio Taxis are widely available and metered. Ride-hailing apps like Uber and Cabify are very popular and generally safer for tourists.
transportation.buses: The 'Colectivo' system is extensive and runs 24/7. You must have a SUBE card to pay; cash is not accepted.
transportation.walking: The city is known as the 'Paris of the South' and is highly walkable, especially in areas like Recoleta and Palermo. Use caution in Microcentro at night.
transportation.airport: Ezeiza (EZE) is the main international hub (45 mins away), while Aeroparque (AEP) is for domestic flights and located within the city limits.

transportation.taxi: Taxis and 'remises' (fixed-rate cars) are common. It is best to call one from a hotel or restaurant rather than hailing on the street.
transportation.buses: Local buses require a SUBE card. There are frequent routes connecting the city center to Llao Llao and the ski base.
transportation.walking: The town center is small and walkable, but most natural attractions require a car or bus due to the mountainous terrain.
transportation.airport: Teniente Luis Candelaria Airport (BRC) is about 15km from the city center. Public buses and shuttles are available.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are affordable and use meters. Remises are also a popular way to visit distant wineries for a flat daily or hourly fee.
transportation.buses: The city has a clean and efficient bus system and a light rail (Metrotranvía) that connects the center to southern suburbs.
transportation.walking: The city is designed with wide, tree-lined avenues and five main plazas, making the downtown area very pleasant for walking.
transportation.airport: Governor Francisco Gabrielli International Airport (MDZ) is a 15-20 minute drive from the city center.

transportation.taxi: Extremely affordable and the most common way to get around. Ride-hailing apps like Yandex Go and GG are highly recommended over hailing on the street.
transportation.buses: The city has a network of buses and 'marshrutkas' (minibuses). There is also a single-line Metro system that is very efficient for crossing the city center.
transportation.walking: The city center (Kentron) is highly walkable and designed with many pedestrian streets, parks, and outdoor cafes.
transportation.airport: Zvartnots International Airport (EVN) is about 15-20 minutes from the center. The Airport Shuttle bus runs every 30 minutes, and app-based taxis are very cheap.

popular attractions: Museum of National Architecture and Urban Life

transportation.taxi: Taxis are the primary mode of transport within the city and are very inexpensive. Walking is preferred for the historic district.
transportation.buses: Minibuses connect the different neighborhoods. The city is also connected to Yerevan via a modern high-speed train.
transportation.walking: The Kumayri district features beautiful 18th and 19th-century black tuff architecture and is best explored on foot.
transportation.airport: Shirak Airport (LWN) serves mainly low-cost carriers and is located just a few kilometers from the city center.

transportation.taxi: Local taxis are available for reaching trailheads and monasteries. Negotiating a daily rate is common for visiting multiple sites.
transportation.buses: Marshrutkas run frequently from Yerevan to Dilijan. Within the town, transport is limited to taxis or walking.
transportation.walking: Dilijan is known as the 'Armenian Switzerland' and is a premier destination for hiking and walking through forested trails.
transportation.airport: There is no local airport; visitors typically drive or take a bus from Yerevan (approx. 1.5 hours).

popular attractions: Art Gallery of New South Wales

transportation.taxi: Taxis and ride-shares (Uber, Ola) are everywhere. Public transport uses the Opal card or contactless credit cards.
transportation.buses: An extensive bus, train, and light rail network. Ferries are also a major part of the public transport system and offer great views.
transportation.walking: The CBD and harbor foreshore are very walkable. Coastal walks, like the Bondi to Coogee path, are world-famous.
transportation.airport: Sydney Airport (SYD) is connected to the city via the Airport Link train (approx. 15 mins) and various shuttle services.

transportation.taxi: Easily available. Uber is the dominant ride-share. The city is famous for its tram network.
transportation.buses: Trams are the primary way to move around the inner city; the 'Free Tram Zone' in the CBD is a major perk for tourists.
transportation.walking: The city layout is a grid, making it very easy to navigate on foot, especially through its famous hidden laneways.
transportation.airport: Melbourne Airport (MEL) is reached by the SkyBus (runs 24/7) or taxi/ride-share, as there is currently no train link.

popular attractions: Queensland Art Gallery & Gallery of Modern Art (QAGOMA)

transportation.taxi: Standard taxis and ride-shares are widely used. TransLink cards (Go Card) or contactless payment are used for public transit.
transportation.buses: The city uses buses, trains, and the 'CityCat' ferry service, which is a popular way to travel along the Brisbane River.
transportation.walking: South Bank and the CBD are highly pedestrianized. The Howard Smith Wharves area is a popular walkable riverside precinct.
transportation.airport: Brisbane Airport (BNE) is connected to the city by the Airtrain (20 mins) and taxis/ride-shares.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are reliable and metered. Ride-sharing apps like Uber and Bolt are widely available. Taxis can be found at designated stands or hailed via phone apps.
transportation.buses: Vienna has an exceptional public transport system including U-Bahn (metro), trams, and buses. A single ticket covers all modes within the city zone.
transportation.walking: The Innere Stadt (District 1) is highly pedestrianized and very walkable. Most major historic sites are within comfortable walking distance of each other.
transportation.airport: Vienna International Airport (VIE) is connected by the City Airport Train (CAT), the S-Bahn (S7), and various airport bus lines.

transportation.taxi: Readily available at the train station and major plazas. Prices are regulated and vehicles are high-quality.
transportation.buses: The city uses an efficient trolleybus (Obus) system. The Salzburg Card offers unlimited use of public transport and free entry to many sights.
transportation.walking: The Old Town (Altstadt) is a UNESCO World Heritage site and is almost entirely pedestrianized, making walking the ideal way to explore.
transportation.airport: Salzburg Airport (SZG) is the second largest in Austria and is located just 20 minutes from the city center by bus line 2 or 10.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are found at the main station and central hubs. They are the best option for late-night travel after public transport stops.
transportation.buses: An integrated network of trams and buses covers the city and surrounding villages. The Hungerburgbahn funicular is a unique part of the transport system.
transportation.walking: The medieval Altstadt is compact and easily explored on foot. Many hiking trails are accessible directly from the city edges.
transportation.airport: Innsbruck Airport (INN) is very close to the city center, reachable in approximately 15 minutes by bus line F.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are plentiful and cheap. Bolt is the most popular and reliable ride-hailing app. Official 'London-style' purple taxis are also common.
transportation.buses: The BakuCard is used for modern red buses and the Baku Metro. The metro is efficient and famous for its ornate station designs.
transportation.walking: The Boulevard and the Old City are perfect for pedestrians. Central Baku is very walkable, though some streets are hilly.
transportation.airport: Heydar Aliyev International Airport (GYD) is connected to the city by the Airport Express bus which runs every 30-60 minutes to 28 May Metro station.

transportation.taxi: Local taxis are the main way for tourists to get around. It is best to agree on a price beforehand or use a ride-hailing app if available.
transportation.buses: Marshrutkas (minibuses) serve most parts of the city and connect to the nearby regions and Baku.
transportation.walking: The central area around the Khan's Garden and the main boulevard is very walkable and pleasant.
transportation.airport: Ganja International Airport (KVD) has flights from Baku and Russia. Taxis are the most reliable way to reach the city center from there.

transportation.taxi: Local taxis are cheap and can be used to reach the Kish village or the fortress ruins outside the main town.
transportation.buses: Minibuses are the standard for travel within the town and for moving between the upper and lower parts of the city.
transportation.walking: The historic center of Sheki is a UNESCO site and is best explored on foot due to its narrow, cobbled streets.
transportation.airport: There is no active commercial airport in Sheki; most visitors arrive by bus or private car from Baku (approx. 4-5 hours).

transportation.taxi: Taxis are available but do not use meters; negotiating the price beforehand is mandatory. For higher security and reliability, hotel-arranged taxis are recommended.
transportation.buses: Minibuses and 'coaster' buses are the primary public transport. They are cheap but often overcrowded and follow irregular schedules.
transportation.walking: The city center is relatively small, but walking long distances is not common for tourists due to safety concerns and humidity. Beach areas are pleasant for walking during the day.
transportation.airport: Bujumbura International Airport (BJM) is the main gateway. It is located about 15-20 minutes from the city center. Taxis are the only reliable connection.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are less frequent than in Bujumbura. Most people rely on 'mototaxis' (motorcycles), which are fast but carry safety risks.
transportation.buses: Intercity buses connect Gitega to Bujumbura and other major towns daily. Inside the city, shared minibuses follow set routes.
transportation.walking: The central administrative area and museum district are walkable. The town is situated on a hill, so expect some steep inclines.
transportation.airport: There is no active commercial airport; visitors typically travel by road from Bujumbura (approx. 2-3 hours).

transportation.taxi: Private taxis are scarce; mototaxis are the primary means of moving quickly between points. Fares should be settled before the ride.
transportation.buses: Buses from Bujumbura and Gitega arrive at the main transport hub. Local travel is dominated by shared minibuses.
transportation.walking: The town is compact and easily navigated on foot, though it is primarily a commercial and agricultural hub rather than a tourist center.
transportation.airport: No local airport; the journey from Bujumbura takes roughly 3.5 to 4 hours by car or bus.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are expensive and strictly regulated. Ride-sharing like Uber is active. Most visitors prefer the integrated STIB/MIVB metro, tram, and bus network.
transportation.buses: Buses and trams are frequent. A STIB ticket works for all city transport. The 'Brussels Card' provides unlimited transport and museum access.
transportation.walking: The central historic core (UNESCO area) is largely pedestrianized and very walkable. Distances between major landmarks like Grand Place and Manneken Pis are short.
transportation.airport: Brussels Airport (BRU) is connected by a direct train (15 mins). Brussels South Charleroi (CRL) is 60km away and requires a shuttle bus (Flibco).

transportation.taxi: Rarely needed inside the city; mostly used for transport to the train station or hotels outside the ring road.
transportation.buses: De Lijn buses serve the city and connect to the railway station, but the historic center is mostly restricted for vehicles.
transportation.walking: Bruges is best explored on foot. The entire historic center is a UNESCO site and is compact enough to cross in 20-30 minutes.
transportation.airport: No local airport; most arrive via train from Brussels (approx. 1 hour).

transportation.taxi: Available at major hubs. Ride-sharing (Uber) is also an option. The city is famous for its efficient pre-metro (underground tram) system.
transportation.buses: The tram and bus network (De Lijn) is extensive. Antwerp is also very bike-friendly, with a popular city-bike sharing scheme (Velo).
transportation.walking: The area between the Central Station and the Scheldt River is highly walkable, featuring the Meir (main shopping street) and historic squares.
transportation.airport: Antwerp International Airport (ANR) has limited flights. Most visitors use Brussels Airport (BRU) and take a 30-minute direct train.

transportation.taxi: Traditional taxis exist, but 'Zémidjans' (motorcycle taxis) are the icon of Cotonou transport. They are fast, cheap, and everywhere; agree on a price before hopping on.
transportation.buses: There is no formal municipal bus system. Shared minibuses ('tokpa-tokpa') follow vague routes and are generally avoided by tourists for comfort reasons.
transportation.walking: Parts of the city like the beach road (Route des Pêches) are walkable, but the city is sprawling, dusty, and traffic-heavy, making walking less practical for long distances.
transportation.airport: Cotonou Cadjehoun International Airport (COO) is located within the city. Taxis and hotel shuttles are the main transport options.

transportation.taxi: There are no cars in Ganvie. Taxis from Cotonou bring you to the Abomey-Calavi pier.
transportation.buses: Not applicable inside the village.
transportation.walking: Not possible; the entire village is on water. All transport is by boat (pirogue). Some guest houses have small platforms, but travel is strictly by water.
transportation.airport: Travelers use Cotonou Airport and then take a 30-minute drive to the pier.

transportation.taxi: Zémidjans are the most common way to get between sites like the town center and the beach. Private cars can be hired for the day from Cotonou.
transportation.buses: Intercity vans run frequently from Cotonou (approx. 45 mins - 1 hour).
transportation.walking: The town center is walkable, and many visitors choose to walk the 4km 'Slave Route' from the city to the beach to see the various monuments.
transportation.airport: No local airport; easy access via the paved highway from Cotonou.

transportation.taxi: Green taxis are ubiquitous but are usually shared; for a private ride, ask for a 'déplacement' and negotiate the fare upfront.
transportation.buses: The SOTRACO city buses are cheap but infrequent; most locals use motorcycles, and tourists often hire private cars with drivers.
transportation.walking: The city center is manageable, but long-distance walking is discouraged due to extreme heat, dust, and heavy traffic.
transportation.airport: Ouagadougou International Airport (OUA) is located nearly in the city center; taxis are the only practical way to reach your hotel.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are the primary way to get around and are generally cheaper than in the capital; motorbike taxis are also available.
transportation.buses: Regular bus lines connect Bobo to Ouagadougou (approx. 5-6 hours); within the city, minibuses are rare.
transportation.walking: The historic Sya district and the area around the Grand Mosque are excellent for exploring on foot with a local guide.
transportation.airport: Bobo-Dioulasso Airport (BOY) has limited flights, primarily connecting to Ouagadougou.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are rare; it is best to hire a driver for the day to visit the waterfalls and the domes.
transportation.buses: Banfora is connected by bus to Bobo-Dioulasso (1.5 hours) and is a stop on the railway line leading to Abidjan.
transportation.walking: The town itself is small, but the main natural attractions are 10-15km away, requiring a vehicle or bicycle.
transportation.airport: No local airport; visitors typically arrive by road or train from Bobo-Dioulasso.

transportation.taxi: Air-conditioned taxis are available, but rickshaws and CNGs (auto-rickshaws) rule the streets; Uber and Pathao are popular for avoiding haggling.
transportation.buses: City buses are extremely crowded and difficult for foreigners to navigate; the new Metro Rail (MRT) is a modern and fast alternative.
transportation.walking: Walking is challenging due to immense crowds and chaotic traffic, except within specific residential areas like Gulshan.
transportation.airport: Hazrat Shahjalal International Airport (DAC) is connected by taxis and ride-sharing apps; traffic to the center can take hours.

popular attractions: Cox's Bazar Beach (Longest in the world)

transportation.taxi: Electric 'Easy-bikes' are the most common way to move along the coast; private cars can be hired for trips to remote beaches.
transportation.buses: Luxury AC buses connect Cox's Bazar to Dhaka (10-12 hours); within the city, rickshaws are the standard.
transportation.walking: Long walks on the sandy beach are the main activity; the tourist zone along the beachfront is safe and pedestrian-friendly.
transportation.airport: Cox's Bazar Airport (CXB) has frequent flights to Dhaka; taxis are readily available at the terminal.

transportation.taxi: CNG auto-rickshaws are the standard; for visiting remote attractions like Jaflong, hiring a private jeep is recommended.
transportation.buses: Local buses are slow; most tourists prefer using private drivers to tour the tea estates and natural sites.
transportation.walking: The areas around the tea gardens are beautiful for light walks, while the city center is noisy and best navigated by vehicle.
transportation.airport: Osmani International Airport (ZYL) receives flights from Dhaka and London; taxis to the city take about 20 minutes.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are affordable; use reputable companies like Yellow or OK Supertrans. The TaxiMe app is highly recommended.
transportation.buses: An excellent system of metro, trams, and trolleybuses; tickets can be purchased using contactless cards directly on the vehicle.
transportation.walking: The city center is compact and full of pedestrian zones; many Roman ruins are located below street level in pedestrian underpasses.
transportation.airport: Sofia Airport (SOF) is connected to the city center via Metro Line 1 (approx. 20 mins).

transportation.taxi: Taxis are very accessible and the fastest way to move outside of the pedestrian-only zones.
transportation.buses: City buses cover the entire city; Plovdiv is also a major rail hub for travel toward Istanbul or Sofia.
transportation.walking: Plovdiv features one of the longest pedestrian streets in Europe; the Old Town is entirely pedestrian but involves cobblestones and slopes.
transportation.airport: Plovdiv Airport (PDV) has few flights; most visitors arrive by train or bus from Sofia (2 hours).

popular attractions: Dormition of the Mother of God Cathedral

transportation.taxi: Taxis are plentiful, but prices in tourist zones can spike in summer; always check the rate sticker on the window.
transportation.buses: There is a good bus network connecting the city with seaside resorts like Golden Sands.
transportation.walking: The seaside promenade and the central pedestrian zone are ideal for walking; the Sea Garden is a massive park along the coast.
transportation.airport: Varna Airport (VAR) is modern and 8km from the center; bus line 409 connects the airport to the city and nearby resorts.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are very affordable; it is recommended to use apps like Moj Taxi or call dispatch centers (Sarajevo Taxi).
transportation.buses: The city has trams (the main artery), trolleybuses, and buses; tickets are bought from the driver or at kiosks.
transportation.walking: The historic center is flat and perfect for walking; exploring the transition from Ottoman to Austro-Hungarian architecture is best done on foot.
transportation.airport: Sarajevo International Airport (SJJ) is connected by a commercial shuttle bus to the Old Town and by taxis.

transportation.taxi: Local taxis are very cheap for rides within the city; for day trips to Blagaj or Kravice, fixed prices are common.
transportation.buses: The 'Mostar Bus' network connects various neighborhoods; Mostar is also famously connected to Sarajevo by one of Europe's most scenic train routes.
transportation.walking: The Old Town is a pedestrian-only zone; be cautious as the 'tenelija' stone on the bridge can be very slippery.
transportation.airport: Mostar Airport (OMO) has seasonal flights; most tourists arrive by bus or train from Sarajevo or Split.

popular attractions: Vrelo Bune (Spring of the Buna River)

transportation.taxi: In Blagaj, taxis are used for the short trip from Mostar; in Jajce, taxis are readily available at the main bus station.
transportation.buses: Jajce is well-connected by intercity lines; Blagaj is reached via local bus #10 from Mostar (runs every 45-60 mins).
transportation.walking: Jajce is an 'open-air museum' best explored on foot; Blagaj is a small village where all sights around the spring are within walking distance.
transportation.airport: No local airports; the closest are in Sarajevo, Mostar, or Banja Luka.

popular attractions: Church of Saints Simon and Helena

transportation.taxi: Taxis are affordable. It is highly recommended to use apps like Yandex Go or Bolt to ensure fixed pricing and avoid language barriers.
transportation.buses: Minsk has a comprehensive public transport system including buses, trolleybuses, and trams. The Minsk Metro is the fastest way to travel across the city.
transportation.walking: The city center is very pedestrian-friendly with wide sidewalks and numerous parks. Independence Avenue is one of the longest city thoroughfares in Europe.
transportation.airport: Minsk National Airport (MSQ) is about 40km from the city. It is connected by a regular shuttle bus (No. 300-E) and taxis.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are the most convenient way to move around. Fares within the city are very low.
transportation.buses: A network of buses and minibuses (marshrutkas) covers the city. Brest is also a major railway hub connecting to Europe and Russia.
transportation.walking: Sovetskaya Street is a beautiful pedestrian-only area where a lamplighter still manually lights the kerosene lamps every evening.
transportation.airport: Brest Airport (BQT) has very limited scheduled flights; most visitors arrive by train or bus from Minsk.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are widely available. Apps like Yandex Go are the preferred method for booking.
transportation.buses: The city is well-served by buses and trolleybuses. Tickets can be purchased at kiosks or from the driver.
transportation.walking: The historic center is compact and largely preserved from WWII, making it one of the most pleasant cities in the country for walking.
transportation.airport: Grodno Airport (GNA) primarily handles seasonal or charter flights; most visitors arrive by land.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are available but most people use golf carts. If using a taxi, agree on the BZD price before starting.
transportation.buses: There are no public buses on the island. Movement is limited to boats, golf carts, and bicycles.
transportation.walking: The main town area is very small and walkable, but the island is long; you will need transport to reach Secret Beach or the northern end.
transportation.airport: San Pedro Airport (SPR) receives frequent small-plane flights from Belize City (15 mins). Water taxis from the mainland are a cheaper alternative (1.5 hours).

transportation.taxi: Taxis are not metered; set a price beforehand. Green license plates signify authorized taxis.
transportation.buses: The main bus terminal connects to all districts in Belize. Within the city, buses are basic and often crowded.
transportation.walking: Walking is okay in the Tourism Village and Fort George areas, but it is not recommended for tourists to walk long distances or explore outside the center at night.
transportation.airport: Philip S.W. Goldson International (BGP) is 15km from the city. Taxis have a fixed rate (~$25 USD).

transportation.taxi: The 'taxis' here are golf carts. There are no cars on the island.
transportation.buses: None. The island’s motto is 'Go Slow'.
transportation.walking: Everything on the island is within a 15-minute walk. The roads are made of sand and unpaved.
transportation.airport: Caye Caulker Airport (CUK) is served by Tropic Air and Maya Island Air. Most visitors arrive via water taxi from Belize City or San Pedro.

popular attractions: Valley of the Moon (Valle de la Luna)

transportation.taxi: Use 'Radio Taxis' (with phone numbers on top) rather than unmarked cars. Apps like Uber and InDrive are popular and safer.
transportation.buses: The city has colorful 'micros' (minibuses). 'PumaKatari' buses are modern, government-run, and much more comfortable for tourists.
transportation.walking: The city is extremely steep and at a very high altitude. Walking is physically demanding; the Teleférico is the best 'transport' for views and ease.
transportation.airport: El Alto International Airport (LPB) is one of the highest in the world. Taxis or airport shuttles are the main ways to descend into the La Paz basin.

transportation.taxi: Local taxis are cheap and plentiful within the small town.
transportation.buses: Buses connect Uyuni to La Paz, Potosi, and Sucre. The town itself is small enough that you won't need buses for local transit.
transportation.walking: The town of Uyuni is very small and flat, making it easy to walk. Most time is spent in 4x4 vehicles for salt flat tours.
transportation.airport: Uyuni Airport (UYU) has daily flights to La Paz. Taxis meet all arriving flights.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are the standard way to reach the mines or the bus terminal. Agree on the fare first.
transportation.buses: Minibuses run set routes through the steep streets. There are frequent bus connections to Sucre (3 hours).
transportation.walking: The colonial center is beautiful but steep and at over 4,000m altitude. Take it very slow to avoid altitude sickness.
transportation.airport: Potosi Airport (POI) has limited domestic service; most travelers arrive by bus from Sucre or Uyuni.

transportation.taxi: Yellow taxis are metered and plentiful. Uber is widely used and often preferred by tourists for safety and tracking.
transportation.buses: The MetroRio is clean, safe, and efficient. City buses (BRT) are extensive but can be confusing and prone to theft; use with caution.
transportation.walking: The beachfront promenades are perfect for walking. In the city center and hills, stick to busy streets and avoid walking alone at night.
transportation.airport: Galeão International (GIG) and Santos Dumont (SDU). Use official airport taxis or Uber; avoid 'private' offers from individuals.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are abundant but expensive. Uber and 99 are the most popular ride-hailing apps.
transportation.buses: The São Paulo Metro is world-class and the best way to avoid the city's infamous traffic jams.
transportation.walking: Avenida Paulista is very walkable, especially on Sundays when closed to cars. Other areas are massive; transport is usually required.
transportation.airport: Guarulhos (GRU) for international and Congonhas (CGH) for domestic. Traffic to GRU can take 1-2 hours depending on the time of day.

popular attractions: Church of Nosso Senhor do Bonfim
Church and Convent of São Francisco

transportation.taxi: Standard taxis are available, but ride-sharing apps (Uber/99) are typically safer and cheaper.
transportation.buses: The city has a new Metro line connecting the airport to the center. Buses are plentiful but stick to the newer 'Salvador Card' buses.
transportation.walking: Pelourinho is a pedestrian-friendly UNESCO site. Use the Elevador Lacerda to move between the Upper and Lower cities.
transportation.airport: Salvador International Airport (SSA) is about 28km from the center, connected via Metro and bus.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are limited in number and often expensive; it is recommended to use the 'Dart' ride-hailing app (Brunei's version of Uber).
transportation.buses: Public buses (purple minibuses) are very affordable but stop running early, usually around 6:00 PM.
transportation.walking: The city center is walkable, and walking along the waterfront provides a great view of the water village.
transportation.airport: Brunei International Airport (BWN) is about 10-15 minutes from the center. Taxis and hotel shuttles are common.

transportation.taxi: No land taxis operate inside the park. Most visitors arrive via organized tour packages from the capital.
transportation.buses: Not available. Access involves a speed boat from BSB to Bangar, followed by a car and then a longboat (temuai).
transportation.walking: Exploration within the park is strictly on foot via wooden boardwalks and steep staircases to the canopy towers.
transportation.airport: No local airport; visitors travel by boat and road from Bandar Seri Begawan (approx. 2 hours).

transportation.taxi: Taxis or Dart are necessary as Jerudong is about 20 minutes outside the city center.
transportation.buses: Buses run from BSB to Jerudong, but service is infrequent and ends early in the evening.
transportation.walking: The park area itself is vast; while walkable once inside, a car is needed to reach the various gates and the nearby Empire resort.
transportation.airport: Approx. 15 minutes from the airport; most visitors use private cars or taxis.

transportation.taxi: Local taxis are the most common way to get to trailheads and nearby sites; prices are often fixed for tourists.
transportation.buses: There is no local city bus system; inter-district buses leave from the main station for Thimphu.
transportation.walking: The main street of Paro is very walkable and charming. However, attractions like Tiger's Nest require a strenuous hike.
transportation.airport: Paro International Airport (PBH) is the only international airport in Bhutan, located very close to the town center.

transportation.taxi: Abundant and easy to find; they use meters or fixed rates. It is the primary way for tourists to visit the Buddha statue.
transportation.buses: A local city bus service exists but is mostly used by locals. Most tourists travel with their mandatory private guide and driver.
transportation.walking: Thimphu is the only capital in the world without traffic lights. The main 'Norzin Lam' street is highly walkable.
transportation.airport: No airport in Thimphu; it is a 1.5-hour scenic drive from Paro Airport.

transportation.taxi: Available in the town centers, but most travel between these distant valleys is done via private tourist vehicles.
transportation.buses: Public buses connect these regions to Thimphu, but the winding mountain roads make for long and bumpy journeys.
transportation.walking: Punakha is warmer and great for walking through rice paddies. Bumthang offers beautiful valley floor walks between monasteries.
transportation.airport: Bathpalathang Airport (BUT) in Bumthang has limited domestic flights from Paro. Punakha is only accessible by road.

transportation.taxi: Local taxis and 'combis' (minibuses) are the primary way to get around town. Taxis are not metered; negotiate before the trip.
transportation.buses: Long-distance buses connect Maun to Gaborone and Francistown. These are generally reliable but slow.
transportation.walking: The town center is small but dusty and hot. Walking is fine for short distances, but most activities require 4x4 vehicles.
transportation.airport: Maun International Airport (MUB) is very busy with light aircraft heading to safari camps. It is located very close to the town center.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are available to transport tourists between lodges and the airport. Most safari activities include pickup.
transportation.buses: Buses run to Francistown and Gaborone. There are also international shuttles to Victoria Falls (Zimbabwe) and Livingstone (Zambia).
transportation.walking: The main road in Kasane is walkable, but be careful as elephants and other wildlife often wander through the town area.
transportation.airport: Kasane Airport (BBK) is just outside town and has flights from Gaborone and Johannesburg.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are common. 'Special' taxis are private, while others are shared. Use the 'InDrive' app for better safety and pricing.
transportation.buses: Combis are the most popular way for locals to move. They follow specific routes and are very cheap.
transportation.walking: The Main Mall and Government enclave are walkable, but the city is sprawling and car-centric.
transportation.airport: Sir Seretse Khama International Airport (GBE) is about 15km from the city; taxis and shuttles are the main link.

popular attractions: Boali Waterfalls (Chutes de Boali - day trip)

transportation.taxi: Yellow taxis are the standard; they are not metered, so negotiate the fare before starting. Shared taxis follow fixed routes and are very cheap.
transportation.buses: Minibuses and shared vans (taxi-brousse) are the main form of public transport. They are often crowded and follow informal schedules.
transportation.walking: The city center and riverside are walkable during the day, but many streets are unpaved and can be muddy or dusty. Avoid walking at night.
transportation.airport: Bangui M'Poko International Airport (BGF) is the main gateway. Use official airport taxis or pre-arranged hotel shuttles for safety.

transportation.taxi: No traditional taxis; transportation is typically handled by safari lodges using 4x4 vehicles.
transportation.buses: Public transport is extremely difficult; most tourists arrive via chartered flights or private 4x4 convoys from Bangui or Cameroon.
transportation.walking: Exploration within the park is strictly on foot with expert trackers and guides through dense rainforest.
transportation.airport: Access is usually via the Bayanga airstrip for charter flights. The journey from Bangui by road can take 12-15 hours.

transportation.taxi: Motorbike taxis (clandos) are the most common way to get around town and nearby villages.
transportation.buses: Bush taxis (taxi-brousse) connect Berbérati to Bangui and the Cameroon border, though the roads are often in poor condition.
transportation.walking: The town center and local markets are easily explored on foot, which is the best way to experience the local pace of life.
transportation.airport: Berbérati Airport (BBT) has an unpaved runway and primarily serves chartered or humanitarian flights.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are metered and everywhere. Uber and Lyft are very popular. The Presto card is used for all public transit.
transportation.buses: The TTC (Toronto Transit Commission) operates an extensive network of subways, streetcars, and buses that run 24/7.
transportation.walking: Downtown Toronto is very walkable, and the PATH (underground walkway) connects miles of the city center, perfect for winter.
transportation.airport: Toronto Pearson (YYZ) is connected to downtown by the UP Express train (25 mins). Billy Bishop (YTZ) is on an island in the harbor.

transportation.taxi: Readily available. The SkyTrain is the jewel of Vancouver transit, being fully automated and providing great views.
transportation.buses: Comprehensive bus and SeaBus (ferry) system. Use a Compass Card for easy travel across all zones.
transportation.walking: Vancouver is known as a 'walking city'. The Seawall is the world's longest uninterrupted waterfront path.
transportation.airport: Vancouver International Airport (YVR) is connected to downtown by the Canada Line (SkyTrain) in about 25 minutes.

transportation.taxi: Plentiful; Uber and Eva (local cooperative) are common. The Metro system is entirely underground and very artistic.
transportation.buses: STM operates a vast bus and metro network. Bixi is one of the world's most successful bike-sharing programs.
transportation.walking: Old Montreal is best seen on foot. In winter, the RESO (underground city) allows people to walk through the CBD indoors.
transportation.airport: Montreal-Trudeau (YUL) is served by the 747 Express Bus (24/7) and taxis. The REM light rail is currently under construction.

popular attractions: Great Wall of China (Badaling or Mutianyu)

transportation.taxi: Taxis are abundant and can be hailed on the street or via the DiDi app (China's version of Uber). Fares are metered but can be expensive during peak traffic.
transportation.buses: The city has an extensive and very inexpensive bus network, though it can be crowded and challenging for non-Mandarin speakers to navigate.
transportation.walking: The central areas around the Forbidden City and various 'Hutongs' (ancient alleys) are very pedestrian-friendly and best explored on foot.
transportation.airport: Beijing Capital International Airport (PEK) and Daxing International (PKX) are connected to the city by dedicated express trains and airport shuttle buses.

transportation.taxi: Similar to Beijing, taxis and DiDi are popular. High-speed Maglev trains also connect Pudong Airport to the city outskirts.
transportation.buses: Shanghai features a modern metro and bus system that is highly efficient and covers almost every corner of the city.
transportation.walking: The Bund and the French Concession are iconic for walking, offering a blend of colonial architecture and modern skylines.
transportation.airport: Pudong International (PVG) is the main international hub, while Hongqiao (SHA) serves mostly domestic and regional flights.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are widely available and generally cheaper than in Beijing or Shanghai. Use the DiDi app for ease of communication.
transportation.buses: Xi'an has a well-developed metro system that connects the main tourist sites like the Bell Tower and the Giant Wild Goose Pagoda.
transportation.walking: Walking atop the ancient City Wall is a popular activity, and the Muslim Quarter is a vibrant pedestrian street famous for street food.
transportation.airport: Xi'an Xianyang International Airport (XIY) is about 45 minutes from the city center, accessible by airport bus and taxi.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are very expensive in Zurich. Uber is available and slightly more affordable, but public transit is preferred.
transportation.buses: An exceptional network of trams and buses. Most visitors use the Swiss Travel Pass or the Zurich Card for unlimited travel.
transportation.walking: The historic city center and the lakeside promenades are highly walkable and very safe.
transportation.airport: Zurich Airport (ZRH) is a major hub and is only a 10-minute train ride from the main central station (HB).

transportation.taxi: Standard taxis are expensive; many tourists opt for the free 'Geneva Transport Card' provided by hotels for local transit.
transportation.buses: Efficient trams and buses run by TPG cover the entire city and even cross into neighboring France.
transportation.walking: The Old Town is hilly but compact. The lakefront paths are flat and perfect for exploring the Jet d'Eau on foot.
transportation.airport: Geneva Airport (GVA) is very close to the city; all arriving passengers can get a free 80-minute transit ticket from machines in the baggage area.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are available but rarely needed for tourists since the town is compact.
transportation.buses: Lucerne has an excellent bus system, and many attractions are reached by cogwheel trains, cable cars, or lake steamers.
transportation.walking: Lucerne is arguably one of the most walkable cities in Europe, with most historic sites concentrated in a car-free zone.
transportation.airport: There is no major airport in Lucerne; most visitors arrive by train from Zurich (approx. 45-60 minutes).

transportation.taxi: Red 'compteur' taxis have meters and are for private use. Orange 'woro-woro' taxis follow set routes and are shared.
transportation.buses: The SOTRA bus system is extensive, and water buses (bateaux-bus) cross the lagoon to avoid traffic.
transportation.walking: The Plateau district is walkable during business hours, but the city is large and traffic-heavy; transport is usually required.
transportation.airport: Félix-Houphouët-Boigny International Airport (ABJ) is connected to the city by taxis and airport shuttles.

popular attractions: Basilica of Our Lady of Peace

transportation.taxi: Green taxis are the main way to get around; since the city has very wide boulevards and little traffic, they are fast and cheap.
transportation.buses: Inter-city buses from Abidjan (3-4 hours) arrive at various private company stations in town.
transportation.walking: The city was designed with massive scale; while the area around the Basilica is walkable, the distances between sites are huge.
transportation.airport: Yamoussoukro International Airport (ASK) has very limited scheduled service; most visitors arrive by road.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are available for local trips, though the historic 'Quartier France' is best explored slowly.
transportation.buses: Frequent minibuses (gbakas) run from Abidjan's Treichville or Adjamé districts (approx. 45-60 minutes).
transportation.walking: The UNESCO World Heritage site of Quartier France is a pedestrian-friendly area perfect for seeing colonial architecture.
transportation.airport: No local airport; it is a short 20-30 minute drive from Abidjan's airport.

transportation.taxi: Yellow taxis are the primary mode of transit. They are shared by default; ask for a 'déplacement' for a private ride and negotiate before entry.
transportation.buses: City buses are rare; 'bendskin' (motorcycle taxis) are common for short hops but can be risky in heavy traffic.
transportation.walking: Walking is common in neighborhoods like Akwa or Bonanjo, but the city is sprawling, humid, and lacks consistent sidewalks.
transportation.airport: Douala International Airport (DLA) is the busiest in the country; official taxis are available outside the terminal.

transportation.taxi: Shared yellow taxis are the standard way to get around the city's seven hills. Private taxis can be hired by the hour.
transportation.buses: Modern coach buses (VIP buses) connect Yaounde to Douala (3.5 hours) but city-wide transit is mostly taxi-based.
transportation.walking: The city is very hilly, making walking strenuous. The central government district is more pedestrian-friendly during the day.
transportation.airport: Yaoundé Nsimalen International Airport (NSI) is about 45 minutes south of the city center.

transportation.taxi: Local taxis in Buea are used to reach the mountain trailheads. Agree on a price for drop-offs at 'Upper Farms'.
transportation.buses: Minibuses and shared taxis connect Buea to the coastal town of Limbe and the city of Douala.
transportation.walking: The primary reason for visiting is the multi-day hike to the summit (4,040m), which must be done with a registered guide.
transportation.airport: No local airport; visitors fly into Douala and take a 1.5-hour car ride to Buea.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are readily available and can be hailed or booked via apps.
transportation.buses: A very efficient network of buses and a world-class metro system serve the city.
transportation.walking: Copenhagen is highly pedestrian and bicycle-friendly, with many historic areas best explored on foot.
transportation.airport: Copenhagen Airport (CPH) is directly connected to the city center by a 15-minute train or metro ride.

transportation.taxi: Available throughout the city and at major transit hubs.
transportation.buses: An extensive local bus network serves the city and surrounding region.
transportation.walking: The compact city center and the Latin Quarter are perfect for walking.
transportation.airport: Aarhus Airport (AAR) is connected to the city by a dedicated airport shuttle bus.

transportation.taxi: Easily available for local trips.
transportation.buses: The city has a reliable bus network and a modern light rail system.
transportation.walking: The historic old town is highly walkable and maintains a fairy-tale charm.
transportation.airport: Most visitors arrive via train from Copenhagen (1.5 hours) rather than local flights.
